VOL. XXX, No. 54

TRACK TEAM DEFEATS
DELAWARE IN LAST
DUAL MEET OF SEASON
Heyn Stars In His Last
Dual Meet For Hopkins
GWINN ELECTED CAPTAIN

Stellar Distance Man To
Lead Team Next Year
Captain Robert E. Heyn, in the
last dual meet in which he wore
the Black and Blue, was once
again the outstanding contestant
when the Johns Hopkins cinder
path men triumphed over the University of Delaware's visiting aggregation. The score was 82 1-6
to 43 5-6.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 18, 1926.

JUNE WEEK PLAY TO
BE PRESENTED TWICE
A Night In An Inn, a one
act play by Lord Dunsany,
will be presented by the
Barnstormers Club on Friday night, May 24, at Prince
of Peace Church in Walbrook and also as part of
June Week program on June
5. I. Evans Rodgers, recently elected president of the
club, is directing the rehearsals and will take a
prominent part in the play.
The cast includes: The Toff
—Jerome Shapiro, Albert
Ralph Townsend; Sniggers—
Evans Rodgers; Bill—Gordon Stick; The Idol—Morton Hamburger, and three
priests—Bennett Kolb, Robert Burnett and Donald
Hiss.

STUDENT COUNCIL HEAD

PRICE 5 CENTS

STADIUM GAME CONFLICTS
WITH J4Y-RAVEN CLASH

It is unfortunate that L'Hirondelle Club plays Princeton in Baltimore on the same
day that the Maryland-Hopkins game will take place.
The Stadium has been secured by L'Hirondelle and
they are expecting and hoping for a large crowd. Although the Princeton-L'Hirondelle is not expected to
furnish as good .lacrosse as
the other game, interest in
this game has increased each
year. Princeton has an exceptionally strong team this
year and last week defeated
Harvard by a score of 9 to 1.
Princeton appeared in Baltimore once before -this year
when the Mount Washington
Club defeated the Tigers in
a closely played game.

Dr. Small Addresses
Junior Class

Again this summer college men
will be given the opportunity,
which was given two years ago, of
enlisting in an industrial research
group which is now being organized by the Y. M. C. A. This
group, which will be comprised of
twenty-five men, will work in the
large industrial plants of Baltimore, and will study the labor
situation. It will start work on
June _21, and disband July 31.
Students interested in work of this
kind should interview Mr. Schall
of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A.
The plans for this industrial
research group are being laid so
that the most favorable opportunity will be had for a close-up study
of the problems of modern industry. The group will meet twice a
week and discuss important industrial questions from every angle.
Speakers, familiar with every
phase of industry, will be secured
to talk to them To facilitate this
study tours will be made through
industrial plants other than those
in which the group is working.
Recreation will be had in the form
of trips to different places near
Baltimore.

Dr. George W. Small, honorary
president of the Class of 1927, addressed the Juniors at their final
class meeting of the year last Friday. As he has obtained a year's
leave for research work in Europe,
Dr. Small will be unable to be
with the class in its senior year.

The Corporation of Yale University has finally concluded that,
under the present conditions at
Yale, compulsory chapel does not
properly advance the religious
tendencies of the undergraduates.
Therefore it has officially abolished this long disliked requirement.
But in view of the fact .that, according to the original charter,
the university was founded to uphold and propagate the Protestant religion, and that it is incumbent upon the university to
see that. this purpose is loyally
fulfilled, President Angell announced that voluntary religious
organizations would be encouraged and supported, and that adequate courses in religion with
credit for a degree would be offered next fall, when the new
order goes into effect.

DELAWARE IN LAST
DUAL MEET OF SEASON
Heyn Stars In His Last
Dual Meet For Hopkins
GWINN ELECTED CAPTAIN

Stellar Distance Man To
Lead Team Next Year
Captain Robert E. Heyn, in the
last dual meet in which he wore
the Black and Blue, was once
again the outstanding contestant
when the Johns Hopkins cinder
path men triumphed over the University of Delaware's visiting aggregation. The score was 82 1-6
to 43 5-6.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 18, 1926.

JUNE WEEK PLAY TO
BE PRESENTED TWICE
A Night In An Inn, a one
act play by Lord Dunsany,
will be presented by the
Barnstormers Club on Friday night, May 24, at Prince
of Peace Church in Walbrook and also as part of
June Week program on June
5. I. Evans Rodgers, recently elected president of the
club, is directing the rehearsals and will take a
prominent part in the play.
The cast includes: The Toff
—Jerome Shapiro, Albert
Ralph Townsend; Sniggers—
Evans Rodgers; Bill—Gordon Stick; The Idol—Morton Hamburger, and three
priests—Bennett Kolb, Robert Burnett and Donald
Hiss.

STUDENT COUNCIL HEAD

PRICE 5 CENTS

STADIUM GAME CONFLICTS
WITH J4Y-RAVEN CLASH

It is unfortunate that L'Hirondelle Club plays Princeton in Baltimore on the same
day that the Maryland-Hopkins game will take place.
The Stadium has been secured by L'Hirondelle and
they are expecting and hoping for a large crowd. Although the Princeton-L'Hirondelle is not expected to
furnish as good .lacrosse as
the other game, interest in
this game has increased each
year. Princeton has an exceptionally strong team this
year and last week defeated
Harvard by a score of 9 to 1.
Princeton appeared in Baltimore once before -this year
when the Mount Washington
Club defeated the Tigers in
a closely played game.

Dr. Small Addresses
Junior Class

Again this summer college men
will be given the opportunity,
which was given two years ago, of
enlisting in an industrial research
group which is now being organized by the Y. M. C. A. This
group, which will be comprised of
twenty-five men, will work in the
large industrial plants of Baltimore, and will study the labor
situation. It will start work on
June _21, and disband July 31.
Students interested in work of this
kind should interview Mr. Schall
of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A.
The plans for this industrial
research group are being laid so
that the most favorable opportunity will be had for a close-up study
of the problems of modern industry. The group will meet twice a
week and discuss important industrial questions from every angle.
Speakers, familiar with every
phase of industry, will be secured
to talk to them To facilitate this
study tours will be made through
industrial plants other than those
in which the group is working.
Recreation will be had in the form
of trips to different places near
Baltimore.

Dr. George W. Small, honorary
president of the Class of 1927, addressed the Juniors at their final
class meeting of the year last Friday. As he has obtained a year's
leave for research work in Europe,
Dr. Small will be unable to be
with the class in its senior year.

The Corporation of Yale University has finally concluded that,
under the present conditions at
Yale, compulsory chapel does not
properly advance the religious
tendencies of the undergraduates.
Therefore it has officially abolished this long disliked requirement.
But in view of the fact .that, according to the original charter,
the university was founded to uphold and propagate the Protestant religion, and that it is incumbent upon the university to
see that. this purpose is loyally
fulfilled, President Angell announced that voluntary religious
organizations would be encouraged and supported, and that adequate courses in religion with
credit for a degree would be offered next fall, when the new
order goes into effect.
